repo.description: Vim-fork focused on extensibility and usability
repo.name: neovim

comment_data.body:
Though the change is valuable, we generally should not add robustness improvements or most bug fixes in news.txt. It's not a changelog, it's a high-level newsletter.

You can ignore the failing "news.txt" CI job, or rename the PR/commit to `fix(..)` which is more appropriate anyway.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -147,6 +147,11 @@ The following changes to existing APIs or features add new behavior.
   resulting in a nvim binary which only could be run headless or embedded
   in an external process. As of this version, TUI is always available.
 
+â€¢ The visual mode default-mappings ('*', '#') were changed to escape the
+  selected text.
+
+  See https://github.com/neovim/neovim/pull/21677.

comment_data.body:
I just noticed that these mappings are peforming a yank, wtf. ðŸ¤¦ 

Instead of another half-measure, may I request that we implement a full solution, as I linked to before: https://github.com/justinmk/config/blob/6e591bad58db8200e8eeebe20982ce3d1fc09c91/.config/nvim/init.vim#L794-L816

The current mappings also don't set `@/`, but they should.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -871,8 +871,8 @@ function vim._init_default_mappings()
   map('n', '<C-L>', '<Cmd>nohlsearch<Bar>diffupdate<Bar>normal! <C-L><CR>')
   map('i', '<C-U>', '<C-G>u<C-U>')
   map('i', '<C-W>', '<C-G>u<C-W>')
-  map('x', '*', 'y/\\V<C-R>"<CR>')
-  map('x', '#', 'y?\\V<C-R>"<CR>')
+  map('x', '*', [[y/\V<C-R>=escape(@", '/\')<CR>]])
+  map('x', '#', [[y?\V<C-R>=escape(@", '?\')<CR>]])

comment_data.body:
> Shouldn't `*` in visual mode also add work boundaries, `\<` and `\>`? vim-asterisk does this

The characters after `\<` and before `\>` must be word characters.

comment_data.body:
> I just noticed that these mappings are peforming a yank, wtf. ðŸ¤¦
> 
> Instead of another half-measure, may I request that we implement a full solution, as I linked to before: https://github.com/justinmk/config/blob/6e591bad58db8200e8eeebe20982ce3d1fc09c91/.config/nvim/init.vim#L794-L816

Correct me if I'm wrong, but this doesn't work when a multibyte character is the last one in a selection.  It only gets the first byte of the last character.

> 
> The current mappings also don't set `@/`, but they should.

The `/` register gets modified with the search command (right after the yank).

comment_data.body:
Could something be built from
```vim
function! VisualSelection() abort
  try
    let unnamed_reg = @"
    let yank_reg = @0
    noautocmd silent! normal! gvy
    return @"
  finally
    let @" = unnamed_reg
    let @0 = yank_reg
  endtry
endfunction

xnoremap * <ESC>/\V<C-R>=substitute(escape(VisualSelection(), '/\'),'\n','\\n','g')<CR><CR>
xnoremap # <ESC>?\V<C-R>=substitute(escape(VisualSelection(), '?\'),'\n','\\n','g')<CR><CR>
```
(I've used [#issuecomment-904514301](https://github.com/neovim/neovim/issues/15471#issuecomment-904514301) and [#issuecomment-1397813214](https://github.com/neovim/neovim/issues/21676#issuecomment-1397813214)) ?
It seems to work.

comment_data.body:
Yes, but here the different affected registers are saved and restored, which is not the case in version 0.9.0 of Neovim. I believe, unless I'm mistaken, that this is what can primarily bother the maintainers.
The = register could have been saved and restored too.

comment_data.body:
`vim.region()` exists, why not use it (it doesn't handle block selection, but that can be a TODO, or fixed)? E.g.

    vim.region(0, "'<", "'>", vim.fn.visualmode(), true)

See also:

- https://github.com/neovim/neovim/pull/13896#issuecomment-1621702052
- #21115
- https://github.com/neovim/neovim/issues/18155

Adding a new public function for _this_ PR should be avoided.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -535,6 +535,55 @@ function vim.region(bufnr, pos1, pos2, regtype, inclusive)
   return region
 end
 
+--- Gets the content of the visual selection.
+---
+--- The result is either a string or, if {list} is `true`, a list of strings.
+--- If not in any |visual-mode|, `nil` is returned.
+---
+--- @param list boolean|nil
+---        Return a list of strings instead of a string.  See |getreg()|.
+---        Defaults to `false`.
+--- @param append_empty boolean|nil
+---        Append an empty string to the result when in |linewise-visual| mode and {list} is `true`.
+---        This will preserve the trailing newline of the selection when the result is concatenated with `"\n"`.
+---        Defaults to `false`.
+--- @return string|table
+function vim.get_visual_selection(list, append_empty)

comment_data.body:
For cases where listing the exact mapping is too much, we can link to the defaults explicitly here. It's useful to have a single place where all the default mappings are linked from.

```
|v_#-default|
|v_star-default|
```

@@ -119,10 +119,11 @@ of these in your config by simply removing the mapping, e.g. ":unmap Y".
 	nnoremap <C-L> <Cmd>nohlsearch<Bar>diffupdate<Bar>normal! <C-L><CR>
 	inoremap <C-U> <C-G>u<C-U>
 	inoremap <C-W> <C-G>u<C-W>
-	xnoremap * y/\V<C-R>"<CR>
-	xnoremap # y?\V<C-R>"<CR>
 	nnoremap & :&&<CR>

+Default mappings composed of Lua code are not listed above. Use ":map" to see
+the |map-listing|.

comment_data.body:
```suggestion
    vim.keymap.set(mode, lhs, rhs, { desc = 'Nvim builtin' })
```
`vim.keymap.set` does not support `noremap` (and `remap=false` is the default anyway)
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -1010,18 +1010,54 @@ end
 function vim._init_default_mappings()
   -- mappings
 
-  --@private
+  ---@private
+  local function region_to_text(region)
+    local text = ''
+    local maxcol = vim.v.maxcol
+    for line, cols in pairs(region) do
+      local endcol = cols[2] == maxcol and -1 or cols[2]
+      local chunk = vim.api.nvim_buf_get_text(0, line, cols[1], line, endcol, {})[1]
+      text = ('%s%s\n'):format(text, chunk)
+    end
+    return text
+  end
+
+  ---@private
+  local function _search_for_visual_selection(search_prefix)
+    if search_prefix ~= '/' and search_prefix ~= '?' then
+      return
+    end
+    -- Escape these characters
+    local replacements = {
+      [search_prefix] = [[\]] .. search_prefix,
+      [ [[\]] ] = [[\\]],
+      ['\t'] = [[\t]],
+      ['\n'] = [[\n]],
+    }
+    local pattern = '[' .. table.concat(vim.tbl_keys(replacements), '') .. ']'
+    local region = vim.region(0, "'<", "'>", vim.fn.visualmode(), true)
+    local visual_selection = region_to_text(region)
+    local escaped_visual_selection = string.gsub(visual_selection, pattern, replacements)
+    local search_cmd = search_prefix .. [[\V]] .. escaped_visual_selection .. '\n'
+    vim.api.nvim_feedkeys(search_cmd, 'nx', true)
+  end
+
+  ---@private
   local function map(mode, lhs, rhs)
-    vim.api.nvim_set_keymap(mode, lhs, rhs, { noremap = true, desc = 'Nvim builtin' })
+    vim.keymap.set(mode, lhs, rhs, { noremap = true, desc = 'Nvim builtin' })

comment_data.body:
Thanks for looking at this.

I first tried using `vim.region` but it was challenging when the last character of a selection was multibyte.  IIRC `vim.region` returns the byte index of the last character selected, but I need to know how many bytes are in that character (to add to the `end_col` param in `nvim_buf_get_text`).

I called `nvim_buf_get_lines` to get the whole line, but I'd still need to find how many bytes are in the last character of the selection.
Given the whole line, I tried using `strgetchar`, `nr2char`, `byteidx`, and `string.sub` in various ways, but it got complicated.

I eventually gave up and used the yank approach because it just works.

Some of my pain points when using the `vim.region`, `nvim_buf_get_lines`, `nvim_buf_get_text` approach:
* `nvim_buf_get_text` does't have a `strict_indexing` option like `nvim_buf_get_lines` has.
* Lua 5.1 isn't Unicode-aware
* The APIs take/return 0-index values, but Lua arrays, row numbers, and column numbers start at 1.  (I know I should "git gud", but I was always second-guessing if I needed to add or subtract 1)
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -535,6 +535,55 @@ function vim.region(bufnr, pos1, pos2, regtype, inclusive)
   return region
 end
 
+--- Gets the content of the visual selection.
+---
+--- The result is either a string or, if {list} is `true`, a list of strings.
+--- If not in any |visual-mode|, `nil` is returned.
+---
+--- @param list boolean|nil
+---        Return a list of strings instead of a string.  See |getreg()|.
+---        Defaults to `false`.
+--- @param append_empty boolean|nil
+---        Append an empty string to the result when in |linewise-visual| mode and {list} is `true`.
+---        This will preserve the trailing newline of the selection when the result is concatenated with `"\n"`.
+---        Defaults to `false`.
+--- @return string|table
+function vim.get_visual_selection(list, append_empty)

comment_data.body:
Those are valid problems, but let's solve them instead of adding a new api. We could (partially?) fix/enhance `vim.region` in Lua-land while waiting on https://github.com/neovim/neovim/pull/21115 .

> nvim_buf_get_text doesn't have a strict_indexing option like nvim_buf_get_lines has. 

Could add a `opts.strict_indexing` flag to nvim_buf_get_text.

> Lua 5.1 isn't Unicode-aware

There is no such thing really ([see also](https://github.com/neovim/neovim/issues/68#issuecomment-170268097)). But `strgetchar`, `strchars`, `strwidth` are available from Lua.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -535,6 +535,55 @@ function vim.region(bufnr, pos1, pos2, regtype, inclusive)
   return region
 end
 
+--- Gets the content of the visual selection.
+---
+--- The result is either a string or, if {list} is `true`, a list of strings.
+--- If not in any |visual-mode|, `nil` is returned.
+---
+--- @param list boolean|nil
+---        Return a list of strings instead of a string.  See |getreg()|.
+---        Defaults to `false`.
+--- @param append_empty boolean|nil
+---        Append an empty string to the result when in |linewise-visual| mode and {list} is `true`.
+---        This will preserve the trailing newline of the selection when the result is concatenated with `"\n"`.
+---        Defaults to `false`.
+--- @return string|table
+function vim.get_visual_selection(list, append_empty)

comment_data.body:
@planet36, when `cmd` is `?`, escaped characters originally were `[[?\]]`. Is there a reason to dropping this?

With current approach, `#` fails on the following example after `v$h#` with cursor on the start of the first line:

```
aa?/\bb
aa
aa?/\bb
```
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -1000,28 +1000,59 @@ function vim.deprecate(name, alternative, version, plugin, backtrace)
   if displayed and backtrace ~= false then
     vim.notify(debug.traceback('', 2):sub(2), vim.log.levels.WARN)
   end
-  if displayed then
-    return msg
-  end
+  return displayed and msg or nil
 end
 
 --- Create builtin mappings (incl. menus).
 --- Called once on startup.
 function vim._init_default_mappings()
   -- mappings
 
-  --@private
+  ---@private
+  local function region_chunks(region)
+    local chunks = {}
+    local maxcol = vim.v.maxcol
+    for line, cols in vim.spairs(region) do
+      local endcol = cols[2] == maxcol and -1 or cols[2]
+      local chunk = vim.api.nvim_buf_get_text(0, line, cols[1], line, endcol, {})[1]
+      table.insert(chunks, chunk)
+    end
+    return chunks
+  end
+
+  ---@private
+  local function _visual_search(cmd)
+    assert(cmd == '/' or cmd == '?')
+    vim.api.nvim_feedkeys('\27', 'nx', true) -- Escape visual mode.
+    local region = vim.region(0, "'<", "'>", vim.fn.visualmode(), vim.o.selection == 'inclusive')
+    local chunks = region_chunks(region)
+    local esc_chunks = vim
+      .iter(chunks)
+      :map(function(v)
+        return vim.fn.escape(v, [[/\]])

comment_regular_data.body: Please don't merge master into your PR branch; it messes up commit history. Instead rebase and force-push.

> Please don't merge master into your PR branch; it messes up commit history. Instead rebase and force-push.

Ok, sorry.  I was using the "Sync fork" button on github.
Yeah, that's a trap; it doesn't do what it seems to promise to do ;)
This PR is ready to be discussed and reviewed.
Pushed an update that uses `vim.region()` instead of adding a new function.
@justinmk So with these changes also add an easy way to get current selected text? `get_visual_selection` will be available outside?

> @justinmk So with these changes also add an easy way to get current selected text? `get_visual_selection` will be available outside?

That isn't in the scope of this PR. See https://github.com/neovim/neovim/pull/21677#discussion_r1252991079 , `vim.region` should be enhanced to better support this, i.e. we should fix its limitations. 

# Status

Currently to get the visual selection you can use the approach shown in this PR:

```lua
local function region_chunks(region)
  local chunks = {}
  local maxcol = vim.v.maxcol
  for line, cols in vim.spairs(region) do
    local endcol = cols[2] == maxcol and -1 or cols[2]
    local chunk = vim.api.nvim_buf_get_text(0, line, cols[1], line, endcol, {})[1]
    table.insert(chunks, chunk)
  end
  return chunks
end


local region = vim.region(0, "'<", "'>", vim.fn.visualmode(), vim.o.selection == 'inclusive')
local chunks = region_chunks(region)
```

- However that has the multibyte limitations discussed in the linked comment. Also doesn't work with visual block selections (`vim.region` bug, should be fixable).
- Followup work:
    - #21115
    - https://github.com/neovim/neovim/issues/18155

> @justinmk So with these changes also add an easy way to get current selected text? `get_visual_selection` will be available outside?

You can add it to your init.lua if it suits your needs.
